Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Interactive Security

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The wide use of wireless data services leads to sensitive and confidential information delivered over wireless links. With e-crimes resulting from such information being compromised to unauthorized parties at an all time high, the ?all wireless? vision can truly materialize only if the security of wireless information transfer can be guaranteed. Conventional approaches to information security are designed for wired networks with assumptions that lead to a disassociation from the physical medium in which communication takes place, and provide guarantees against adversaries that are computationally limited. This project provides a new approach for wireless networks to deliver provable and unconditional security.

This research designs wireless networks with a secure foundation guaranteeing reliable and secure delivery of information. In doing so, the investigators account for untapped and rich resources provided by wireless systems naturally, including sources with correlated observations or application content, channels that provide spatial and temporal diversity, network nodes that are helpers or relays providing interaction, and broadcast and bi-directional nature of the medium enabling communication with feedback. The project calls for a network design paradigm that has security in its foundation and provides enlightened system design principles and protocols that are optimized to jointly exploit these resources. Some examples of this, which form the intellectual backbone of this project, include the optimal use of correlated sources and broadcast channels, the role of multinode interaction, the opportunistic use of potentially untrusted relay nodes, the creative use of feedback channels, in order to render intelligent and computationally unlimited (passive and active) adversaries ineffective. An extended goal is to integrate the resulting design principles for unconditional security with cryptographic approaches towards exploiting synergies between the two.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless networks are particularly vulnerable to security threats due to their inherent openness. This project has focused on providing security for wireless communication networks using information-theoretic security guarantees, which implies that the methods developed are valid irrespective of the computational powers of the adversaries. Of the two important security threats encountered in wireless communications, namely jamming and eavesdropping threats, this project has focused on the eavesdropping attack, and developed transmission and cooperation techniques, that guarantee security of communication even against computationally-unlimited eavesdroppers.

The major technical outcome of this project is the development of techniques to achieve information-theoretic security in multi-terminal wireless networks. This project determined the exact secure capacities and the corresponding optimum signalling schemes for several network structures, for instance, for the multiple-antenna multi-receiver wiretap channel. This project developed cooperation mechanisms with untrusted partners in a network, for instance, for the relay broadcast channel. This project developed secure source coding techniques for lossless and lossy source coding scenarios. In addition, this project determined the exact secure degrees of freedom of several network structures, including the helper wiretap channel, multiple access wiretap channel and the interference wiretap channel. To this end, this project developed several secure signal alignment methods.

Educational and outreach outcomes of this project include the development of a graduate-level course on information-theoretic security for wireless communications at the University of Maryland, and offering of several half-day and full-day tutorials at international conferences and graduate-student summer schools. In addition, the PIs have written several expository and review articles on wireless physical layer security intended for general audiences.

Human development and training outcomes of this project include training of several PhD students here at Maryland, and at Penn State and UC Berkeley (our collaborative partners in this project) on wireless physical layer security, wireless communication theory and secure networking, and network information theory. These PhD students have had the opportunity to interact and collaborate with their peers and faculty at different institutions through this project, which enhanced their learning and research experiences.
